description: From Middle English surprise, borrowed from Middle French surprise (“an overtake”), nominal use of the past participle of Old French sorprendre (“to overtake”), from sor- (“over”) + prendre (“to take”), from Latin super- + Latin prendere, contracted from prehendere (“to grasp, seize”). Doublet of suppli.

examples: It was a surprise to find out I owed twice as much as I thought I did.

entries.meaning: The feeling that something unexpected has happened.
examples: Imagine my surprise on learning I owed twice as much as I thought I did.

verbs.description: surprise (third-person singular simple present surprises, present participle surprising, simple past and past participle surprised)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (someone) to feel unusually alarmed or delighted by something unexpected.
examples: It surprises me that I owe twice as much as I thought I did.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To do something to (a person) that they are not expecting, as a surprise.
examples: He doesn’t know that I’m in the country – I thought I’d turn up at his house and surprise him.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To undergo or witness something unexpected.
